title: Alphabet Faces Regulatory Uncertainty as DOJ Decision Nears
description: Alphabet Inc. is drawing heightened attention this week as investors await the Department of Justice’s next move in its long-running antitrust battle.
content:
Alphabet Inc. is drawing heightened attention this week as investors await the Department of Justice’s next move in its long-running antitrust battle. According to Yahoo! Finance, the U.S. District Court has already ruled that Google unlawfully maintained its dominance in online search and related advertising markets through exclusionary default agreements.

By completing this form, you agree to receive marketing communications from PYMNTS and to the sharing of your information with our sponsor, if applicable, in accordance with our Privacy Policy and Terms and Conditions .

Complete the form to unlock this article and enjoy unlimited free access to all PYMNTS content — no additional logins required.

Analysts at BMO Capital warn that Alphabet’s share price could swing by as much as 10% in either direction depending on the remedies imposed. Per Yahoo! Finance, Judge Amit Mehta is expected to issue his decision shortly, aiming to resolve the matter before the launch of the government’s separate Ad-Tech trial.

Read more: Google Offers Play Store Changes to Avoid EU Penalties

BMO Capital anticipates that the remedies will be meaningful but not extreme. The firm expects regulators to push for a broad behavioral consent decree rather than a forced breakup. Such a measure could restrict Google’s practices around distribution agreements, data sharing, and competitive conduct, potentially extending to artificial intelligence operations. While divestitures of assets like Chrome or Android appear unlikely, the author notes that any restrictions could still weigh heavily on Google’s core revenue streams and flexibility.

The greater threat, however, may lie in the upcoming Ad-Tech case. Analysts cited by Yahoo! Finance point out that this proceeding carries a much higher chance of a structural breakup, with a decision on remedies projected after September 2025. Combined, the two antitrust cases could expose Alphabet to a decade of heightened regulatory oversight, reshaping the competitive dynamics of search and digital advertising.
summary: Alphabet Inc. is facing uncertainty as the Department of Justice (Dj.E.M. decides its next move in its long-running antitrust battle against Google, which has been ruled that it unlawfully maintained its dominance in online search and related advertising markets through exclusionary default agreements. Analysts at B.nownstately, they predict that the company's share price could fluctuate by up to 10% depending on the outcome of the case. The decision on remedies is expected to be made by Judge Amit Mehta shortly, aiming to resolve the matter before the government’s separate Ad-Tech trial.
shortSummary: Alphabet's stock rose as investors awaited the Department of Justice's next decision on its antitrust case, potentially leading to a structural breakup.

scraped_sources.text:
Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOGL) is one of the Trending AI Stocks in Focus This Week. According to BMO Capital, the U.S. District Court has already found Google guilty of “illegally maintaining its search monopoly in general search and search text advertising via exclusionary default agreements.”
In lights of this, analysts at the firm have highlighted that Google’s stock may fluctuate as much as 10% in either direction based on the Department of Justice’s upcoming decision.
Judge Amit Mehta’s decision on the appropriate remedies is anticipated very soon “to clear the deck ahead of the new Ad-Tech trial starting shortly.”
BMO Capital believes that the upcoming remedies for the search monopoly case are going to be significant but not “Draconian.”
It also believes that the most probable outcome would be “a comprehensive behavioral consent decree—not a structural breakup—imposing lasting constraints on Google’s distribution practices, data sharing, and competitive behavior, potentially including AI.”’
While Google is likely to avoid being forced to divest Chrome or Android, though any remedies “could directly impact core revenue streams and operating flexibility.”
The larger risk, however, is in the upcoming Ad-Tech antitrust case. This is because it “presents a higher probability of a structural breakup, with a ruling on remedies expected after September 2025.”
The two cases can together push Google toward “a decade of heightened regulatory oversight and fundamentally alter the competitive landscape for search and digital advertising.”
While we acknowledge the potential of GOOGL as an investment, we believe certain AI stocks offer greater upside potential and carry less downside risk. Disclosure: None.

argos_summary: Alphabet Inc. faces a looming DOJ antitrust decision after a U.S. District Court ruled that Google unlawfully maintained dominance in search and advertising through exclusionary agreements. BMO Capital warns that the company’s stock could swing up to 10% depending on the remedies, which are expected to be a broad behavioral consent decree rather than a forced breakup, potentially restricting distribution, data sharing, and AI practices. While divestitures of Chrome or Android are unlikely, the imposed constraints could still affect core revenue streams. A separate, higher‑risk Ad‑Tech case may lead to a structural breakup, with a decision anticipated after September 2025, potentially subjecting Alphabet to a decade of intensified regulatory scrutiny and reshaping the competitive landscape of search and digital advertising.
